The date or period when the detected issue was initially identified.

DetectedIssue.short: The provider or device that identified the issue
DetectedIssue.definition: Individual or device responsible for the issue being raised.  For example, a decision support application or a pharmacist conducting a medication review.
Indicates the resource representing the current activity or proposed activity that is potentially problematic.
DetectedIssue.comment: There's an implicit constraint on the number of implicated resources based on DetectedIssue.type; e.g. For drug-drug, there would be more than one.  For timing, there would typically only be one.

DetectedIssue.definition: Supporting evidence or manifestations that provide the basis for identifying the detected issue such as a GuidanceResponse or MeasureReport.
A manifestation that led to the recording of this detected issue.

binding.description: Codes that describes the types of evidence for a detected issue.

DetectedIssue.definition: Links to resources that constitute evidence for the detected issue such as a GuidanceResponse or MeasureReport.
A textual explanation of the detected issue.
DetectedIssue.comment: Should focus on information not covered elsewhere as discrete data - no need to duplicate the narrative.

DetectedIssue.definition: The literature, knowledge-base or similar reference that describes the propensity for the detected issue identified.

Indicates an action that has been taken or is committed to reduce or eliminate the likelihood of the risk identified by the detected issue from manifesting.  Can also reflect an observation of known mitigating factors that may reduce/eliminate the need for any action.
Describes the action that was taken or the observation that was made that reduces/eliminates the risk associated with the identified issue.
DetectedIssue.comment: The "text" component can be used for detail or when no appropriate code exists.

binding.description: Codes describing steps taken to resolve the issue or other circumstances that mitigate the risk associated with the issue; e.g. 'added concurrent therapy', 'prior therapy documented', etc.

DetectedIssue.definition: Indicates when the mitigating action was documented.
DetectedIssue.comment: This might not be the same as when the mitigating step was actually taken.

DetectedIssue.definition: Identifies the practitioner who determined the mitigation and takes responsibility for the mitigation step occurring.

Device.definition: Unique instance identifiers assigned to a device by manufacturers other organizations or owners.
Device.comment: The barcode string from a barcode present on a device label or package may identify the instance, include names given to the device in local usage, or may identify the type of device. If the identifier identifies the type of device, Device.type element should be used.

Device.short: The reference to the definition for the device
Device.definition: The reference to the definition for the device.

Unique device identifier (UDI) assigned to device label or package.  Note that the Device may include multiple udiCarriers as it either may include just the udiCarrier for the jurisdiction it is sold, or for multiple jurisdictions it could have been sold.
Device.comment: UDI may identify an unique instance of a device, or it may only identify the type of the device.  See [UDI mappings](device-mappings.html#udi) for a complete mapping of UDI parts to Device.

Device.definition: The device identifier (DI) is a mandatory, fixed portion of a UDI that identifies the labeler and the specific version or model of a device.

Organization that is charged with issuing UDIs for devices.  For example, the US FDA issuers include : 1) GS1:  http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/gs1-di,  2) HIBCC: http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/hibcc-dI,  3) ICCBBA for blood containers: http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/iccbba-blood-di,  4) ICCBA for other devices: http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/iccbba-other-di.

The identity of the authoritative source for UDI generation within a  jurisdiction.  All UDIs are globally unique within a single namespace with the appropriate repository uri as the system.  For example,  UDIs of devices managed in the U.S. by the FDA, the value is  http://hl7.org/fhir/NamingSystem/fda-udi.

The full UDI carrier of the Automatic Identification and Data Capture (AIDC) technology representation of the barcode string as printed on the packaging of the device - e.g., a barcode or RFID.   Because of limitations on character sets in XML and the need to round-trip JSON data through XML, AIDC Formats *SHALL* be base64 encoded.
Device.comment: The AIDC form of UDIs should be scanned or otherwise used for the identification of the device whenever possible to minimize errors in records resulting from manual transcriptions. If separate barcodes for DI and PI are present, concatenate the string with DI first and in order of human readable expression on label.

Device.definition: The full UDI carrier as the human readable form (HRF) representation of the barcode string as printed on the packaging of the device.
Device.comment: If separate barcodes for DI and PI are present, concatenate the string with DI first and in order of human readable expression on label.

Device.definition: A coded entry to indicate how the data was entered.

binding.description: Codes to identify how UDI data was entered.

Device.definition: Status of the Device availability.
Device.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes inactive and entered-in-error that mark the device (record)as not currently valid.

binding.description: The availability status of the device.

Device.short: online | paused | standby | offline | not-ready | transduc-discon | hw-discon | off
Device.definition: Reason for the dtatus of the Device availability.

binding.description: The availability status reason of the device.

Device.definition: The distinct identification string as required by regulation for a human cell, tissue, or cellular and tissue-based product.
Device.comment: For example, this applies to devices in the United States regulated under *Code of Federal Regulation 21CFR1271.290(c)*.

Device.definition: A name of the manufacturer.

Device.short: Date when the device was made
Device.definition: The date and time when the device was manufactured.

Device.short: Date and time of expiry of this device (if applicable)
Device.definition: The date and time beyond which this device is no longer valid or should not be used (if applicable).
Lot number assigned by the manufacturer.

Device.short: Serial number assigned by the manufacturer
Device.definition: The serial number assigned by the organization when the device was manufactured.

Device.short: The name of the device as given by the manufacturer
Device.definition: This represents the manufacturer's name of the device as provided by the device, from a UDI label, or by a person describing the Device.  This typically would be used when a person provides the name(s) or when the device represents one of the names available from DeviceDefinition.
The name of the device.

Device.short: udi-label-name | user-friendly-name | patient-reported-name | manufacturer-name | model-name | other
Device.definition: The type of deviceName. UDILabelName | UserFriendlyName | PatientReportedName | ManufactureDeviceName | ModelName.

binding.description: The type of name the device is referred by.

Device.short: The model number for the device
Device.definition: The model number for the device.

Device.short: The part number of the device
Device.definition: The part number of the device.

Device.short: The kind or type of device
Device.definition: The kind or type of device.

binding.description: Codes to identify medical devices.

Device.short: The capabilities supported on a  device, the standards to which the device conforms for a particular purpose, and used for the communication
Device.definition: The capabilities supported on a  device, the standards to which the device conforms for a particular purpose, and used for the communication.

Device.short: The standard that is used to operate and communicate
Device.definition: The standard that is used to operate and communicate.

Device.short: The version of the standard that is used to operate and communicate
Device.definition: The version of the standard that is used to operate and communicate.

Device.short: The actual design of the device or software version running on the device
Device.definition: The actual design of the device or software version running on the device.

Device.short: The type of the device version
Device.definition: The type of the device version.

Device.short: A single component of the device version
Device.definition: A single component of the device version.
The version text.

Device.short: The actual configuration settings of a device as it actually operates, e.g., regulation status, time properties
Device.definition: The actual configuration settings of a device as it actually operates, e.g., regulation status, time properties.

Device.short: Code that specifies the property DeviceDefinitionPropetyCode (Extensible)
Device.definition: Code that specifies the property DeviceDefinitionPropetyCode (Extensible).
Property value as a quantity.

Device.short: Property value as a code, e.g., NTP4 (synced to NTP)
Device.definition: Property value as a code, e.g., NTP4 (synced to NTP).

Device.short: Patient to whom Device is affixed
Device.definition: Patient information, If the device is affixed to a person.
An organization that is responsible for the provision and ongoing maintenance of the device.
Contact details for an organization or a particular human that is responsible for the device.
The place where the device can be found.
A network address on which the device may be contacted directly.
Device.comment: If the device is running a FHIR server, the network address should  be the Base URL from which a conformance statement may be retrieved.

Device.definition: Descriptive information, usage information or implantation information that is not captured in an existing element.
Provides additional safety characteristics about a medical device.  For example devices containing latex.
The parent device.

DeviceDefinition.short: Instance identifier
DeviceDefinition.definition: Unique instance identifiers assigned to a device by the software, manufacturers, other organizations or owners. For example: handle ID.

DeviceDefinition.short: Unique Device Identifier (UDI) Barcode string
DeviceDefinition.definition: Unique device identifier (UDI) assigned to device label or package.  Note that the Device may include multiple udiCarriers as it either may include just the udiCarrier for the jurisdiction it is sold, or for multiple jurisdictions it could have been sold.

DeviceDefinition.short: The identifier that is to be associated with every Device that references this DeviceDefintiion for the issuer and jurisdication porvided in the DeviceDefinition.udiDeviceIdentifier
DeviceDefinition.definition: The identifier that is to be associated with every Device that references this DeviceDefintiion for the issuer and jurisdication porvided in the DeviceDefinition.udiDeviceIdentifier.

DeviceDefinition.short: The organization that assigns the identifier algorithm
DeviceDefinition.definition: The organization that assigns the identifier algorithm.

DeviceDefinition.short: The jurisdiction to which the deviceIdentifier applies
DeviceDefinition.definition: The jurisdiction to which the deviceIdentifier applies.

DeviceDefinition.short: Name of device manufacturer
DeviceDefinition.definition: A name of the manufacturer.

DeviceDefinition.short: A name given to the device to identify it
DeviceDefinition.definition: A name given to the device to identify it.

DeviceDefinition.short: The name of the device
DeviceDefinition.definition: The name of the device.

DeviceDefinition.short: udi-label-name | user-friendly-name | patient-reported-name | manufacturer-name | model-name | other
DeviceDefinition.definition: The type of deviceName. UDILabelName | UserFriendlyName | PatientReportedName | ManufactureDeviceName | ModelName.

binding.description: The type of name the device is referred by.

DeviceDefinition.short: The model number for the device
DeviceDefinition.definition: The model number for the device.

DeviceDefinition.short: What kind of device or device system this is
DeviceDefinition.definition: What kind of device or device system this is.

binding.description: Type of device e.g. according to official classification.

DeviceDefinition.short: The capabilities supported on a  device, the standards to which the device conforms for a particular purpose, and used for the communication
DeviceDefinition.definition: The capabilities supported on a  device, the standards to which the device conforms for a particular purpose, and used for the communication.

DeviceDefinition.short: The standard that is used to operate and communicate
DeviceDefinition.definition: The standard that is used to operate and communicate.

DeviceDefinition.short: The version of the standard that is used to operate and communicate
DeviceDefinition.definition: The version of the standard that is used to operate and communicate.

DeviceDefinition.short: Available versions
DeviceDefinition.definition: The available versions of the device, e.g., software versions.

DeviceDefinition.short: Safety characteristics of the device
DeviceDefinition.definition: Safety characteristics of the device.

DeviceDefinition.short: Shelf Life and storage information
DeviceDefinition.definition: Shelf Life and storage information.

DeviceDefinition.short: Dimensions, color etc.
DeviceDefinition.definition: Dimensions, color etc.

DeviceDefinition.short: Language code for the human-readable text strings produced by the device (all supported)
DeviceDefinition.definition: Language code for the human-readable text strings produced by the device (all supported).

DeviceDefinition.short: Device capabilities
DeviceDefinition.definition: Device capabilities.

DeviceDefinition.short: Type of capability
DeviceDefinition.definition: Type of capability.

DeviceDefinition.short: Description of capability
DeviceDefinition.definition: Description of capability.

DeviceDefinition.short: The actual configuration settings of a device as it actually operates, e.g., regulation status, time properties
DeviceDefinition.definition: The actual configuration settings of a device as it actually operates, e.g., regulation status, time properties.

DeviceDefinition.short: Code that specifies the property DeviceDefinitionPropetyCode (Extensible)
DeviceDefinition.definition: Code that specifies the property DeviceDefinitionPropetyCode (Extensible).

DeviceDefinition.short: Property value as a quantity
DeviceDefinition.definition: Property value as a quantity.

DeviceDefinition.short: Property value as a code, e.g., NTP4 (synced to NTP)
DeviceDefinition.definition: Property value as a code, e.g., NTP4 (synced to NTP).

DeviceDefinition.short: Organization responsible for device
DeviceDefinition.definition: An organization that is responsible for the provision and ongoing maintenance of the device.

DeviceDefinition.short: Details for human/organization for support
DeviceDefinition.definition: Contact details for an organization or a particular human that is responsible for the device.

DeviceDefinition.short: Network address to contact device
DeviceDefinition.definition: A network address on which the device may be contacted directly.
DeviceDefinition.comment: If the device is running a FHIR server, the network address should  be the Base URL from which a conformance statement may be retrieved.

DeviceDefinition.short: Access to on-line information
DeviceDefinition.definition: Access to on-line information about the device.

DeviceDefinition.short: Device notes and comments
DeviceDefinition.definition: Descriptive information, usage information or implantation information that is not captured in an existing element.

DeviceDefinition.short: The quantity of the device present in the packaging (e.g. the number of devices present in a pack, or the number of devices in the same package of the medicinal product)
DeviceDefinition.definition: The quantity of the device present in the packaging (e.g. the number of devices present in a pack, or the number of devices in the same package of the medicinal product).

DeviceDefinition.short: The parent device it can be part of
DeviceDefinition.definition: The parent device it can be part of.

DeviceDefinition.short: A substance used to create the material(s) of which the device is made
DeviceDefinition.definition: A substance used to create the material(s) of which the device is made.

DeviceDefinition.short: The substance
DeviceDefinition.definition: The substance.

DeviceDefinition.short: Indicates an alternative material of the device
DeviceDefinition.definition: Indicates an alternative material of the device.

DeviceDefinition.short: Whether the substance is a known or suspected allergen
DeviceDefinition.definition: Whether the substance is a known or suspected allergen.

DeviceMetric.definition: Unique instance identifiers assigned to a device by the device or gateway software, manufacturers, other organizations or owners. For example: handle ID.
DeviceMetric.comment: For identifiers assigned to a device by the device or gateway software, the `system` element of the identifier should be set to the unique identifier of the device.

DeviceMetric.short: Identity of metric, for example Heart Rate or PEEP Setting
DeviceMetric.definition: Describes the type of the metric. For example: Heart Rate, PEEP Setting, etc.
DeviceMetric.comment: DeviceMetric.type can be referred to either IEEE 11073-10101 or LOINC.

binding.description: Describes the metric type.

DeviceMetric.short: Unit of Measure for the Metric
DeviceMetric.definition: Describes the unit that an observed value determined for this metric will have. For example: Percent, Seconds, etc.
DeviceMetric.comment: DeviceMetric.unit can refer to either UCUM or preferable a RTMMS coding system.

binding.description: Describes the unit of the metric.

DeviceMetric.short: Describes the link to the source Device
DeviceMetric.definition: Describes the link to the  Device that this DeviceMetric belongs to and that contains administrative device information such as manufacturer, serial number, etc.

DeviceMetric.short: Describes the link to the parent Device
DeviceMetric.definition: Describes the link to the  Device that this DeviceMetric belongs to and that provide information about the location of this DeviceMetric in the containment structure of the parent Device. An example would be a Device that represents a Channel. This reference can be used by a client application to distinguish DeviceMetrics that have the same type, but should be interpreted based on their containment location.
Indicates current operational state of the device. For example: On, Off, Standby, etc.

binding.description: Describes the operational status of the DeviceMetric.

DeviceMetric.short: black | red | green | yellow | blue | magenta | cyan | white
DeviceMetric.definition: Describes the color representation for the metric. This is often used to aid clinicians to track and identify parameter types by color. In practice, consider a Patient Monitor that has ECG/HR and Pleth for example; the parameters are displayed in different characteristic colors, such as HR-blue, BP-green, and PR and SpO2- magenta.

binding.description: Describes the typical color of representation.

DeviceMetric.definition: Indicates the category of the observation generation process. A DeviceMetric can be for example a setting, measurement, or calculation.

binding.description: Describes the category of the metric.

DeviceMetric.definition: Describes the measurement repetition time. This is not necessarily the same as the update period. The measurement repetition time can range from milliseconds up to hours. An example for a measurement repetition time in the range of milliseconds is the sampling rate of an ECG. An example for a measurement repetition time in the range of hours is a NIBP that is triggered automatically every hour. The update period may be different than the measurement repetition time, if the device does not update the published observed value with the same frequency as it was measured.

DeviceMetric.short: Describes the calibrations that have been performed or that are required to be performed
DeviceMetric.definition: Describes the calibrations that have been performed or that are required to be performed.
Describes the type of the calibration method.

binding.description: Describes the type of a metric calibration.

DeviceMetric.definition: Describes the state of the calibration.

binding.description: Describes the state of a metric calibration.

DeviceMetric.short: Describes the time last calibration has been performed
DeviceMetric.definition: Describes the time last calibration has been performed.

DeviceRequest.definition: Identifiers assigned to this order by the orderer or by the receiver.
The URL pointing to a FHIR-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this DeviceRequest.
DeviceRequest.comment: Note: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](resource.html#identifiers)).  It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types.  For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

DeviceRequest.definition: The URL pointing to an externally maintained protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this DeviceRequest.
DeviceRequest.comment: This might be an HTML page, PDF, etc. or could just be a non-resolvable URI identifier.

DeviceRequest.definition: Plan/proposal/order fulfilled by this request.
The request takes the place of the referenced completed or terminated request(s).
Composite request this is part of.

DeviceRequest.short: draft | active | suspended | completed | entered-in-error | cancelled
DeviceRequest.definition: The status of the request.
DeviceRequest.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes cancelled and entered-in-error that mark the request as not currently valid.

binding.description: Codes representing the status of the request.

DeviceRequest.definition: Whether the request is a proposal, plan, an original order or a reflex order.

binding.description: The kind of diagnostic request.

DeviceRequest.short: Indicates how quickly the {{title}} should be addressed with respect to other requests
DeviceRequest.definition: Indicates how quickly the {{title}} should be addressed with respect to other requests.

binding.description: Identifies the level of importance to be assigned to actioning the request.

DeviceRequest.definition: The details of the device to be used.

binding.description: Codes for devices that can be requested.

DeviceRequest.definition: Specific parameters for the ordered item.  For example, the prism value for lenses.
A code or string that identifies the device detail being asserted.

binding.description: A code that identifies the device detail.

DeviceRequest.definition: The value of the device detail.
DeviceRequest.comment: Range means device should have a value that falls somewhere within the specified range.

DeviceRequest.definition: The patient who will use the device.
An encounter that provides additional context in which this request is made.

DeviceRequest.short: Desired time or schedule for use
DeviceRequest.definition: The timing schedule for the use of the device. The Schedule data type allows many different expressions, for example. "Every 8 hours"; "Three times a day"; "1/2 an hour before breakfast for 10 days from 23-Dec 2011:"; "15 Oct 2013, 17 Oct 2013 and 1 Nov 2013".
When the request transitioned to being actionable.
The individual who initiated the request and has responsibility for its activation.
Desired type of performer for doing the diagnostic testing.

binding.description: Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care team, such as "Primary physician", "Team coordinator", "Caregiver", etc.

DeviceRequest.definition: The desired performer for doing the diagnostic testing.
Reason or justification for the use of this device.

binding.description: Diagnosis or problem codes justifying the reason for requesting the device.

DeviceRequest.definition: Reason or justification for the use of this device.
Insurance plans, coverage extensions, pre-authorizations and/or pre-determinations that may be required for delivering the requested service.
Additional clinical information about the patient that may influence the request fulfilment.  For example, this may include where on the subject's body the device will be used (i.e. the target site).

Details about this request that were not represented at all or sufficiently in one of the attributes provided in a class. These may include for example a comment, an instruction, or a note associated with the statement.
Key events in the history of the request.
DeviceRequest.comment: This might not include provenances for all versions of the request - only those deemed "relevant" or important. This SHALL NOT include the Provenance associated with this current version of the resource.  (If that provenance is deemed to be a "relevant" change, it will need to be added as part of a later update.  Until then, it can be queried directly as the Provenance that points to this version using _revinclude All Provenances should have some historical version of this Request as their subject.

DeviceUseStatement.definition: An external identifier for this statement such as an IRI.
A plan, proposal or order that is fulfilled in whole or in part by this DeviceUseStatement.
A code representing the patient or other source's judgment about the state of the device used that this statement is about.  Generally this will be active or completed.
DeviceUseStatement.comment: DeviceUseStatment is a statement at a point in time.  The status is only representative at the point when it was asserted.  The value set for contains codes that assert the status of the use  by the patient (for example, stopped or on hold) as well as codes that assert the status of the resource itself (for example, entered in error).  This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes that mark the statement as not currently valid.

binding.description: A coded concept indicating the current status of the Device Usage.

DeviceUseStatement.definition: The patient who used the device.
Allows linking the DeviceUseStatement to the underlying Request, or to other information that supports or is used to derive the DeviceUseStatement.
DeviceUseStatement.comment: The most common use cases for deriving a DeviceUseStatement comes from creating it from a request or from an observation or a claim. it should be noted that the amount of information that is available varies from the type resource that you derive the DeviceUseStatement from.

DeviceUseStatement.short: How often  the device was used
DeviceUseStatement.definition: How often the device was used.
The time at which the statement was made/recorded.
Who reported the device was being used by the patient.
The details of the device used.
Reason or justification for the use of the device.
Indicates another resource whose existence justifies this DeviceUseStatement.
Indicates the anotomic location on the subject's body where the device was used ( i.e. the target).

binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

DeviceUseStatement.definition: Details about the device statement that were not represented at all or sufficiently in one of the attributes provided in a class. These may include for example a comment, an instruction, or a note associated with the statement.

DiagnosticReport.definition: Identifiers assigned to this report by the performer or other systems.
DiagnosticReport.comment: Usually assigned by the Information System of the diagnostic service provider (filler id).

DiagnosticReport.definition: Details concerning a service requested.
DiagnosticReport.comment: Note: Usually there is one test request for each result, however in some circumstances multiple test requests may be represented using a single test result resource. Note that there are also cases where one request leads to multiple reports.

DiagnosticReport.definition: The status of the diagnostic report.

binding.description: The status of the diagnostic report.

DiagnosticReport.definition: A code that classifies the clinical discipline, department or diagnostic service that created the report (e.g. cardiology, biochemistry, hematology, MRI). This is used for searching, sorting and display purposes.
DiagnosticReport.comment: Multiple categories are allowed using various categorization schemes.   The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set. More fine-grained filtering can be performed using the metadata and/or terminology hierarchy in DiagnosticReport.code.

binding.description: Codes for diagnostic service sections.

DiagnosticReport.definition: A code or name that describes this diagnostic report.

binding.description: Codes that describe Diagnostic Reports.

DiagnosticReport.short: The subject of the report - usually, but not always, the patient
DiagnosticReport.definition: The subject of the report. Usually, but not always, this is a patient. However, diagnostic services also perform analyses on specimens collected from a variety of other sources.

DiagnosticReport.short: Health care event when test ordered
DiagnosticReport.definition: The healthcare event  (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) which this DiagnosticReport is about.
DiagnosticReport.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some events may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter  but still be tied to the context of the encounter  (e.g. pre-admission laboratory tests).

DiagnosticReport.definition: The time or time-period the observed values are related to. When the subject of the report is a patient, this is usually either the time of the procedure or of specimen collection(s), but very often the source of the date/time is not known, only the date/time itself.
DiagnosticReport.comment: If the diagnostic procedure was performed on the patient, this is the time it was performed. If there are specimens, the diagnostically relevant time can be derived from the specimen collection times, but the specimen information is not always available, and the exact relationship between the specimens and the diagnostically relevant time is not always automatic.

DiagnosticReport.definition: The date and time that this version of the report was made available to providers, typically after the report was reviewed and verified.
DiagnosticReport.comment: May be different from the update time of the resource itself, because that is the status of the record (potentially a secondary copy), not the actual release time of the report.

DiagnosticReport.definition: The diagnostic service that is responsible for issuing the report.
DiagnosticReport.comment: This is not necessarily the source of the atomic data items or the entity that interpreted the results. It is the entity that takes responsibility for the clinical report.

DiagnosticReport.definition: The practitioner or organization that is responsible for the report's conclusions and interpretations.
DiagnosticReport.comment: Might not be the same entity that takes responsibility for the clinical report.

DiagnosticReport.short: Specimens this report is based on
DiagnosticReport.definition: Details about the specimens on which this diagnostic report is based.
DiagnosticReport.comment: If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the test result name, then this additional data may be redundant. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per observation or group.

DiagnosticReport.definition: [Observations](observation.html)  that are part of this diagnostic report.

DiagnosticReport.short: Reference to full details of imaging associated with the diagnostic report
DiagnosticReport.definition: One or more links to full details of any imaging performed during the diagnostic investigation. Typically, this is imaging performed by DICOM enabled modalities, but this is not required. A fully enabled PACS viewer can use this information to provide views of the source images.
DiagnosticReport.comment: ImagingStudy and the image element are somewhat overlapping - typically, the list of image references in the image element will also be found in one of the imaging study resources. However, each caters to different types of displays for different types of purposes. Neither, either, or both may be provided.

DiagnosticReport.short: Key images associated with this report
DiagnosticReport.definition: A list of key images associated with this report. The images are generally created during the diagnostic process, and may be directly of the patient, or of treated specimens (i.e. slides of interest).
A comment about the image. Typically, this is used to provide an explanation for why the image is included, or to draw the viewer's attention to important features.
DiagnosticReport.comment: The comment should be displayed with the image. It would be common for the report to include additional discussion of the image contents in other sections such as the conclusion.

DiagnosticReport.definition: Reference to the image source.
Concise and clinically contextualized summary conclusion (interpretation/impression) of the diagnostic report.

DiagnosticReport.short: Codes for the clinical conclusion of test results
DiagnosticReport.definition: One or more codes that represent the summary conclusion (interpretation/impression) of the diagnostic report.

binding.description: Diagnosis codes provided as adjuncts to the report.

DiagnosticReport.definition: Rich text representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they SHALL be semantically equivalent.
DiagnosticReport.comment: "application/pdf" is recommended as the most reliable and interoperable in this context.

DocumentManifest.short: Unique Identifier for the set of documents
DocumentManifest.definition: A single identifier that uniquely identifies this manifest. Principally used to refer to the manifest in non-FHIR contexts.
Other identifiers associated with the document manifest, including version independent  identifiers.
The status of this document manifest.
DocumentManifest.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes that mark the manifest as not currently valid.

binding.description: The status of the document reference.

DocumentManifest.definition: The code specifying the type of clinical activity that resulted in placing the associated content into the DocumentManifest.
DocumentManifest.comment: Specifies the kind of this set of documents (e.g. Patient Summary, Discharge Summary, Prescription, etc.). The type of a set of documents may be the same as one of the documents in it - especially if there is only one - but it may be wider.

binding.description: The activity that caused the DocumentManifest to be created.

DocumentManifest.short: The subject of the set of documents
DocumentManifest.definition: Who or what the set of documents is about. The documents can be about a person, (patient or healthcare practitioner), a device (i.e. machine) or even a group of subjects (such as a document about a herd of farm animals, or a set of patients that share a common exposure). If the documents cross more than one subject, then more than one subject is allowed here (unusual use case).
When the document manifest was created for submission to the server (not necessarily the same thing as the actual resource last modified time, since it may be modified, replicated, etc.).
DocumentManifest.comment: Creation time is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching. This is the creation time of the document set, not the documents on which it is based.

DocumentManifest.short: Who and/or what authored the DocumentManifest
DocumentManifest.definition: Identifies who is the author of the manifest. Manifest author is not necessarly the author of the references included.
DocumentManifest.comment: Not necessarily who did the actual data entry (i.e. typist) or who was the source (informant).

DocumentManifest.short: Intended to get notified about this set of documents
DocumentManifest.definition: A patient, practitioner, or organization for which this set of documents is intended.
DocumentManifest.comment: How the recipient receives the document set or is notified of it is up to the implementation. This element is just a statement of intent. If the recipient is a person, and it is not known whether the person is a patient or a practitioner, RelatedPerson would be the default choice.

DocumentManifest.definition: Identifies the source system, application, or software that produced the document manifest.
Human-readable description of the source document. This is sometimes known as the "title".
DocumentManifest.comment: What the document is about, rather than a terse summary of the document. It is commonly the case that records do not have a title and are collectively referred to by the display name of Record code (e.g. a "consultation" or "progress note").

DocumentManifest.definition: The list of Resources that consist of the parts of this manifest.
DocumentManifest.comment: When used for XDS the intended focus of the DocumentManifest is for the reference to target to be a set of DocumentReference Resources. The reference is to "Any" to support EN 13606 usage, where an extract is DocumentManifest that references  List and Composition resources.

DocumentManifest.definition: Related identifiers or resources associated with the DocumentManifest.
DocumentManifest.comment: May be identifiers or resources that caused the DocumentManifest to be created.

DocumentManifest.short: Identifiers of things that are related
DocumentManifest.definition: Related identifier to this DocumentManifest.  For example, Order numbers, accession numbers, XDW workflow numbers.
DocumentManifest.comment: If both identifier and ref elements are present they shall refer to the same thing.

DocumentManifest.definition: Related Resource to this DocumentManifest. For example, Order, ServiceRequest,  Procedure, EligibilityRequest, etc.
DocumentManifest.comment: If both identifier and ref elements are present they shall refer to the same thing.

DocumentReference.definition: Document identifier as assigned by the source of the document. This identifier is specific to this version of the document. This unique identifier may be used elsewhere to identify this version of the document.
DocumentReference.comment: CDA Document Id extension and root.

DocumentReference.definition: Other identifiers associated with the document, including version independent identifiers.
The status of this document reference.
DocumentReference.comment: This is the status of the DocumentReference object, which might be independent from the docStatus element.  This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the codes that mark the document or reference as not currently valid.

binding.description: The status of the document reference.

DocumentReference.definition: The status of the underlying document.
DocumentReference.comment: The document that is pointed to might be in various lifecycle states.

binding.description: Status of the underlying document.

DocumentReference.definition: Specifies the particular kind of document referenced  (e.g. History and Physical, Discharge Summary, Progress Note). This usually equates to the purpose of making the document referenced.
DocumentReference.comment: Key metadata element describing the document that describes he exact type of document. Helps humans to assess whether the document is of interest when viewing a list of documents.

binding.description: Precise type of clinical document.

DocumentReference.definition: A categorization for the type of document referenced - helps for indexing and searching. This may be implied by or derived from the code specified in the DocumentReference.type.
DocumentReference.comment: Key metadata element describing the the category or classification of the document. This is a broader perspective that groups similar documents based on how they would be used. This is a primary key used in searching.

binding.description: High-level kind of a clinical document at a macro level.

DocumentReference.short: Who/what is the subject of the document
DocumentReference.definition: Who or what the document is about. The document can be about a person, (patient or healthcare practitioner), a device (e.g. a machine) or even a group of subjects (such as a document about a herd of farm animals, or a set of patients that share a common exposure).

DocumentReference.short: When this document reference was created
DocumentReference.definition: When the document reference was created.
DocumentReference.comment: Referencing/indexing time is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching.

DocumentReference.short: Who and/or what authored the document
DocumentReference.definition: Identifies who is responsible for adding the information to the document.
DocumentReference.comment: Not necessarily who did the actual data entry (i.e. typist) or who was the source (informant).

DocumentReference.definition: Which person or organization authenticates that this document is valid.
DocumentReference.comment: Represents a participant within the author institution who has legally authenticated or attested the document. Legal authentication implies that a document has been signed manually or electronically by the legal Authenticator.

DocumentReference.definition: Identifies the organization or group who is responsible for ongoing maintenance of and access to the document.
DocumentReference.comment: Identifies the logical organization (software system, vendor, or department) to go to find the current version, where to report issues, etc. This is different from the physical location (URL, disk drive, or server) of the document, which is the technical location of the document, which host may be delegated to the management of some other organization.

DocumentReference.definition: Relationships that this document has with other document references that already exist.
DocumentReference.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because documents that append to other documents are incomplete on their own.

DocumentReference.definition: The type of relationship that this document has with anther document.
DocumentReference.comment: If this document appends another document, then the document cannot be fully understood without also accessing the referenced document.

binding.description: The type of relationship between documents.

DocumentReference.definition: The target document of this relationship.
Human-readable description of the source document.
DocumentReference.comment: What the document is about,  a terse summary of the document.

DocumentReference.definition: A set of Security-Tag codes specifying the level of privacy/security of the Document. Note that DocumentReference.meta.security contains the security labels of the "reference" to the document, while DocumentReference.securityLabel contains a snapshot of the security labels on the document the reference refers to.
DocumentReference.comment: The confidentiality codes can carry multiple vocabulary items. HL7 has developed an understanding of security and privacy tags that might be desirable in a Document Sharing environment, called HL7 Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System (HCS). The following specification is recommended but not mandated, as the vocabulary bindings are an administrative domain responsibility. The use of this method is up to the policy domain such as the XDS Affinity Domain or other Trust Domain where all parties including sender and recipients are trusted to appropriately tag and enforce.     In the HL7 Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification (HCS) there are code systems specific to Confidentiality, Sensitivity, Integrity, and Handling Caveats. Some values would come from a local vocabulary as they are related to workflow roles and special projects.

binding.description: Security Labels from the Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System.

DocumentReference.definition: The document and format referenced. There may be multiple content element repetitions, each with a different format.
The document or URL of the document along with critical metadata to prove content has integrity.
An identifier of the document encoding, structure, and template that the document conforms to beyond the base format indicated in the mimeType.
DocumentReference.comment: Note that while IHE mostly issues URNs for format types, not all documents can be identified by a URI.

binding.description: Document Format Codes.

DocumentReference.definition: The clinical context in which the document was prepared.
DocumentReference.comment: These values are primarily added to help with searching for interesting/relevant documents.

DocumentReference.definition: Describes the clinical encounter or type of care that the document content is associated with.

This list of codes represents the main clinical acts, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented. In some cases, the event is inherent in the type Code, such as a "History and Physical Report" in which the procedure being documented is necessarily a "History and Physical" act.
DocumentReference.comment: An event can further specialize the act inherent in the type, such as  where it is simply "Procedure Report" and the procedure was a "colonoscopy". If one or more event codes are included, they shall not conflict with the values inherent in the class or type elements as such a conflict would create an ambiguous situation.

binding.description: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts being documented.

DocumentReference.short: Time of service that is being documented
DocumentReference.definition: The time period over which the service that is described by the document was provided.

DocumentReference.short: Kind of facility where patient was seen
DocumentReference.definition: The kind of facility where the patient was seen.

binding.description: XDS Facility Type.

DocumentReference.short: Additional details about where the content was created (e.g. clinical specialty)
DocumentReference.definition: This property may convey specifics about the practice setting where the content was created, often reflecting the clinical specialty.
DocumentReference.comment: This element should be based on a coarse classification system for the class of specialty practice. Recommend the use of the classification system for Practice Setting, such as that described by the Subject Matter Domain in LOINC.

binding.description: Additional details about where the content was created (e.g. clinical specialty).

DocumentReference.definition: The Patient Information as known when the document was published. May be a reference to a version specific, or contained.
Related identifiers or resources associated with the DocumentReference.
DocumentReference.comment: May be identifiers or resources that caused the DocumentReference or referenced Document to be created.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: Canonical identifier for this effect evidence synthesis, represented as a URI (globally unique)
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this effect evidence synthesis when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this effect evidence synthesis is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the effect evidence synthesis is stored on different servers.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.  The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).   In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: Additional identifier for the effect evidence synthesis
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this effect evidence synthesis when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this effect evidence synthesis outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: Business version of the effect evidence synthesis
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the effect evidence synthesis when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the effect evidence synthesis author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: There may be different effect evidence synthesis instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the effect evidence synthesis with the format [url]|[version].

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: Name for this effect evidence synthesis (computer friendly)
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A natural language name identifying the effect evidence synthesis. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: Name for this effect evidence synthesis (human friendly)
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the effect evidence synthesis.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: The status of this effect evidence synthesis. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: Allows filtering of effect evidence synthesiss that are appropriate for use versus not.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the effect evidence synthesis was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the effect evidence synthesis changes.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the effect evidence synthesis. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the effect evidence synthesis.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the effect evidence synthesis is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the effect evidence synthesis. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the effect evidence synthesis. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: Natural language description of the effect evidence synthesis
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A free text natural language description of the effect evidence synthesis from a consumer's perspective.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the effect evidence synthesis was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the effect evidence synthesis as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the effect evidence synthesis is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the effect evidence synthesis was created).

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: Used for footnotes or explanatory notes
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A human-readable string to clarify or explain concepts about the resource.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: The context that the content is intended to support
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate effect evidence synthesis instances.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: Intended jurisdiction for effect evidence synthesis (if applicable)
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the effect evidence synthesis is intended to be used.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: It may be possible for the effect evidence synthesis to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A copyright statement relating to the effect evidence synthesis and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the effect evidence synthesis.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: When the effect evidence synthesis was approved by publisher
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: When the effect evidence synthesis was last reviewed
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: If specified, this date follows the original approval date.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: When the effect evidence synthesis is expected to be used
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: The period during which the effect evidence synthesis content was or is planned to be in active use.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: The effective period for a effect evidence synthesis  determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: The category of the EffectEvidenceSynthesis, such as Education, Treatment, Assessment, etc.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: Descriptive topics related to the content of the EffectEvidenceSynthesis. Topics provide a high-level categorization grouping types of EffectEvidenceSynthesiss that can be useful for filtering and searching.

binding.description: High-level categorization of the definition, used for searching, sorting, and filtering.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: An individiual or organization primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the content.
An individual or organization primarily responsible for internal coherence of the content.
An individual or organization primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the content.
An individual or organization responsible for officially endorsing the content for use in some setting.
Related artifacts such as additional documentation, justification, or bibliographic references.
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.comment: Each related artifact is either an attachment, or a reference to another resource, but not both.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: Type of synthesis eg meta-analysis.

binding.description: Types of combining results from a body of evidence (eg. summary data meta-analysis).

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: Type of study eg randomized trial.

binding.description: Types of research studies (types of research methods).

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A reference to a EvidenceVariable resource that defines the population for the research.
A reference to a EvidenceVariable resource that defines the exposure for the research.
A reference to a EvidenceVariable resource that defines the comparison exposure for the research.
A reference to a EvidenceVariable resomece that defines the outcome for the research.
A description of the size of the sample involved in the synthesis.
Human-readable summary of sample size.
Number of studies included in this evidence synthesis.
Number of participants included in this evidence synthesis.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: What was the result per exposure?
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A description of the results for each exposure considered in the effect estimate.
Human-readable summary of results by exposure state.
Whether these results are for the exposure state or alternative exposure state.

binding.description: Whether the results by exposure is describing the results for the primary exposure of interest (exposure) or the alternative state (exposureAlternative).

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: Used to define variant exposure states such as low-risk state.

binding.description: Used for results by exposure in variant states such as low-risk, medium-risk and high-risk states.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: Reference to a RiskEvidenceSynthesis resource.
The estimated effect of the exposure variant.
Human-readable summary of effect estimate.
Examples include relative risk and mean difference.

binding.description: Whether the effect estimate is an absolute effect estimate (absolute difference) or a relative effect estimate (relative difference), and the specific type of effect estimate (eg relative risk or median difference).

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: Used to define variant exposure states such as low-risk state.

binding.description: Used for results by exposure in variant states such as low-risk, medium-risk and high-risk states.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: The point estimate of the effect estimate.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: What unit is the outcome described in?
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: Specifies the UCUM unit for the outcome.

binding.description: Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM).

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A description of the precision of the estimate for the effect.
Examples include confidence interval and interquartile range.

binding.description: Method of reporting variability of estimates, such as confidence intervals, interquartile range or standard deviation.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: Use 95 for a 95% confidence interval.
Lower bound of confidence interval.
Upper bound of confidence interval.
A description of the certainty of the effect estimate.
A rating of the certainty of the effect estimate.

binding.description: The quality of the evidence described. The code system used specifies the quality scale used to grade this evidence source while the code specifies the actual quality score (represented as a coded value) associated with the evidence.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: Used for footnotes or explanatory notes
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A human-readable string to clarify or explain concepts about the resource.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: A component that contributes to the overall certainty
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A description of a component of the overall certainty.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: Type of subcomponent of certainty rating
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: Type of subcomponent of certainty rating.

binding.description: The subcomponent classification of quality of evidence rating systems.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A rating of a subcomponent of rating certainty.

binding.description: The quality rating of the subcomponent of a quality of evidence rating.

EffectEvidenceSynthesis.short: Used for footnotes or explanatory notes
EffectEvidenceSynthesis.definition: A human-readable string to clarify or explain concepts about the resource.

Encounter.short: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known
Encounter.definition: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known.

Encounter.short: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +
Encounter.definition: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +.
Encounter.comment: Note that internal business rules will determine the appropriate transitions that may occur between statuses (and also classes).

binding.description: Current state of the encounter.

Encounter.short: List of past encounter statuses
Encounter.definition: The status history permits the encounter resource to contain the status history without needing to read through the historical versions of the resource, or even have the server store them.
Encounter.comment: The current status is always found in the current version of the resource, not the status history.

Encounter.short: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +
Encounter.definition: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +.

binding.description: Current state of the encounter.

Encounter.short: The time that the episode was in the specified status
Encounter.definition: The time that the episode was in the specified status.

Encounter.short: Classification of patient encounter
Encounter.definition: Concepts representing classification of patient encounter such as ambulatory (outpatient), inpatient, emergency, home health or others due to local variations.

binding.description: Classification of the encounter.

Encounter.short: List of past encounter classes
Encounter.definition: The class history permits the tracking of the encounters transitions without needing to go  through the resource history.  This would be used for a case where an admission starts of as an emergency encounter, then transitions into an inpatient scenario. Doing this and not restarting a new encounter ensures that any lab/diagnostic results can more easily follow the patient and not require re-processing and not get lost or cancelled during a kind of discharge from emergency to inpatient.

Encounter.short: inpatient | outpatient | ambulatory | emergency +
Encounter.definition: inpatient | outpatient | ambulatory | emergency +.

binding.description: Classification of the encounter.

Encounter.short: The time that the episode was in the specified class
Encounter.definition: The time that the episode was in the specified class.

Encounter.short: Specific type of encounter
Encounter.definition: Specific type of encounter (e.g. e-mail consultation, surgical day-care, skilled nursing, rehabilitation).
Encounter.comment: Since there are many ways to further classify encounters, this element is 0..*.

binding.description: The type of encounter.

Encounter.short: Specific type of service
Encounter.definition: Broad categorization of the service that is to be provided (e.g. cardiology).

binding.description: Broad categorization of the service that is to be provided.

Encounter.short: Indicates the urgency of the encounter
Encounter.definition: Indicates the urgency of the encounter.

binding.description: Indicates the urgency of the encounter.

Encounter.short: The patient or group present at the encounter
Encounter.definition: The patient or group present at the encounter.
Encounter.comment: While the encounter is always about the patient, the patient might not actually be known in all contexts of use, and there may be a group of patients that could be anonymous (such as in a group therapy for Alcoholics Anonymous - where the recording of the encounter could be used for billing on the number of people/staff and not important to the context of the specific patients) or alternately in veterinary care a herd of sheep receiving treatment (where the animals are not individually tracked).

Encounter.short: Episode(s) of care that this encounter should be recorded against
Encounter.definition: Where a specific encounter should be classified as a part of a specific episode(s) of care this field should be used. This association can facilitate grouping of related encounters together for a specific purpose, such as government reporting, issue tracking, association via a common problem.  The association is recorded on the encounter as these are typically created after the episode of care and grouped on entry rather than editing the episode of care to append another encounter to it (the episode of care could span years).

Encounter.short: The ServiceRequest that initiated this encounter
Encounter.definition: The request this encounter satisfies (e.g. incoming referral or procedure request).

Encounter.short: List of participants involved in the encounter
Encounter.definition: The list of people responsible for providing the service.

Encounter.short: Role of participant in encounter
Encounter.definition: Role of participant in encounter.
Encounter.comment: The participant type indicates how an individual participates in an encounter. It includes non-practitioner participants, and for practitioners this is to describe the action type in the context of this encounter (e.g. Admitting Dr, Attending Dr, Translator, Consulting Dr). This is different to the practitioner roles which are functional roles, derived from terms of employment, education, licensing, etc.

binding.description: Role of participant in encounter.

Encounter.short: Period of time during the encounter that the participant participated
Encounter.definition: The period of time that the specified participant participated in the encounter. These can overlap or be sub-sets of the overall encounter's period.

Encounter.short: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient
Encounter.definition: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient.

Encounter.short: The appointment that scheduled this encounter
Encounter.definition: The appointment that scheduled this encounter.

Encounter.short: The start and end time of the encounter
Encounter.definition: The start and end time of the encounter.
Encounter.comment: If not (yet) known, the end of the Period may be omitted.

Encounter.short: Quantity of time the encounter lasted (less time absent)
Encounter.definition: Quantity of time the encounter lasted. This excludes the time during leaves of absence.
Encounter.comment: May differ from the time the Encounter.period lasted because of leave of absence.

Encounter.short: Coded reason the encounter takes place
Encounter.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
Encounter.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

binding.description: Reason why the encounter takes place.

Encounter.short: Reason the encounter takes place (reference)
Encounter.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
Encounter.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

Encounter.short: The list of diagnosis relevant to this encounter
Encounter.definition: The list of diagnosis relevant to this encounter.

Encounter.short: The diagnosis or procedure relevant to the encounter
Encounter.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, as specified using information from another resource. For admissions, this is the admission diagnosis. The indication will typically be a Condition (with other resources referenced in the evidence.detail), or a Procedure.
Encounter.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

Encounter.short: Role that this diagnosis has within the encounter (e.g. admission, billing, discharge )
Encounter.definition: Role that this diagnosis has within the encounter (e.g. admission, billing, discharge ).

binding.description: The type of diagnosis this condition represents.

Encounter.short: Ranking of the diagnosis (for each role type)
Encounter.definition: Ranking of the diagnosis (for each role type).

Encounter.short: The set of accounts that may be used for billing for this Encounter
Encounter.definition: The set of accounts that may be used for billing for this Encounter.
Encounter.comment: The billing system may choose to allocate billable items associated with the Encounter to different referenced Accounts based on internal business rules.

Encounter.short: Details about the admission to a healthcare service
Encounter.definition: Details about the admission to a healthcare service.
Encounter.comment: An Encounter may cover more than just the inpatient stay. Contexts such as outpatients, community clinics, and aged care facilities are also included.  The duration recorded in the period of this encounter covers the entire scope of this hospitalization record.

Encounter.short: Pre-admission identifier
Encounter.definition: Pre-admission identifier.

Encounter.short: The location/organization from which the patient came before admission
Encounter.definition: The location/organization from which the patient came before admission.

Encounter.short: From where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer)
Encounter.definition: From where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer).

binding.description: From where the patient was admitted.

Encounter.short: The type of hospital re-admission that has occurred (if any). If the value is absent, then this is not identified as a readmission
Encounter.definition: Whether this hospitalization is a readmission and why if known.

binding.description: The reason for re-admission of this hospitalization encounter.

Encounter.short: Diet preferences reported by the patient
Encounter.definition: Diet preferences reported by the patient.
Encounter.comment: For example, a patient may request both a dairy-free and nut-free diet preference (not mutually exclusive).

binding.description: Medical, cultural or ethical food preferences to help with catering requirements.

Encounter.short: Special courtesies (VIP, board member)
Encounter.definition: Special courtesies (VIP, board member).

binding.description: Special courtesies.

Encounter.short: Wheelchair, translator, stretcher, etc.
Encounter.definition: Any special requests that have been made for this hospitalization encounter, such as the provision of specific equipment or other things.

binding.description: Special arrangements.

Encounter.short: Location/organization to which the patient is discharged
Encounter.definition: Location/organization to which the patient is discharged.

Encounter.short: Category or kind of location after discharge
Encounter.definition: Category or kind of location after discharge.

binding.description: Discharge Disposition.

Encounter.short: List of locations where the patient has been
Encounter.definition: List of locations where  the patient has been during this encounter.
Encounter.comment: Virtual encounters can be recorded in the Encounter by specifying a location reference to a location of type "kind" such as "client's home" and an encounter.class = "virtual".

Encounter.short: Location the encounter takes place
Encounter.definition: The location where the encounter takes place.

Encounter.short: planned | active | reserved | completed
Encounter.definition: The status of the participants' presence at the specified location during the period specified. If the participant is no longer at the location, then the period will have an end date/time.
Encounter.comment: When the patient is no longer active at a location, then the period end date is entered, and the status may be changed to completed.

binding.description: The status of the location.

Encounter.short: The physical type of the location (usually the level in the location hierachy - bed room ward etc.)
Encounter.definition: This will be used to specify the required levels (bed/ward/room/etc.) desired to be recorded to simplify either messaging or query.
Encounter.comment: This information is de-normalized from the Location resource to support the easier understanding of the encounter resource and processing in messaging or query.  There may be many levels in the hierachy, and this may only pic specific levels that are required for a specific usage scenario.

binding.description: Physical form of the location.

Encounter.short: Time period during which the patient was present at the location
Encounter.definition: Time period during which the patient was present at the location.

Encounter.short: The organization (facility) responsible for this encounter
Encounter.definition: The organization that is primarily responsible for this Encounter's services. This MAY be the same as the organization on the Patient record, however it could be different, such as if the actor performing the services was from an external organization (which may be billed seperately) for an external consultation.  Refer to the example bundle showing an abbreviated set of Encounters for a colonoscopy.

Encounter.short: Another Encounter this encounter is part of
Encounter.definition: Another Encounter of which this encounter is a part of (administratively or in time).
Encounter.comment: This is also used for associating a child's encounter back to the mother's encounter.  Refer to the Notes section in the Patient resource for further details.

Endpoint.short: Identifies this endpoint across multiple systems
Endpoint.definition: Identifier for the organization that is used to identify the endpoint across multiple disparate systems.

Endpoint.short: active | suspended | error | off | entered-in-error | test
Endpoint.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the endpoint as not currently valid.

binding.description: The status of the endpoint.

Endpoint.short: Protocol/Profile/Standard to be used with this endpoint connection
Endpoint.definition: A coded value that represents the technical details of the usage of this endpoint, such as what WSDLs should be used in what way. (e.g. XDS.b/DICOM/cds-hook).
Endpoint.comment: For additional connectivity details for the protocol, extensions will be used at this point, as in the XDS example.

Endpoint.short: A name that this endpoint can be identified by
Endpoint.definition: A friendly name that this endpoint can be referred to with.

Endpoint.short: Organization that manages this endpoint (might not be the organization that exposes the endpoint)
Endpoint.definition: The organization that manages this endpoint (even if technically another organization is hosting this in the cloud, it is the organization associated with the data).
Endpoint.comment: This property is not typically used when searching for Endpoint resources for usage. The typical usage is via the reference from an applicable Organization/Location/Practitioner resource, which is where the context is provided. Multiple Locations may reference a single endpoint, and don't have to be within the same organization resource, but most likely within the same organizational hierarchy.

Endpoint.definition: Contact details for a human to contact about the subscription. The primary use of this for system administrator troubleshooting.

Endpoint.short: Interval the endpoint is expected to be operational
Endpoint.definition: The interval during which the endpoint is expected to be operational.

Endpoint.short: The type of content that may be used at this endpoint (e.g. XDS Discharge summaries)
Endpoint.definition: The payload type describes the acceptable content that can be communicated on the endpoint.
Endpoint.comment: The payloadFormat describes the serialization format of the data, where the payloadType indicates the specific document/schema that is being transferred; e.g. DischargeSummary or CarePlan.

Endpoint.short: Mimetype to send. If not specified, the content could be anything (including no payload, if the connectionType defined this)
Endpoint.definition: The mime type to send the payload in - e.g. application/fhir+xml, application/fhir+json. If the mime type is not specified, then the sender could send any content (including no content depending on the connectionType).
Endpoint.comment: Sending the payload has obvious security consequences. The server is responsible for ensuring that the content is appropriately secured.

binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

Endpoint.short: The technical base address for connecting to this endpoint
Endpoint.definition: The uri that describes the actual end-point to connect to.
