The identifier assigned by the lab when accessioning specimen(s). This is not necessarily the same as the specimen identifier, depending on local lab procedures.
The availability of the specimen.
Specimen.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.description: Codes providing the status/availability of a specimen.

Specimen.short: Kind of material that forms the specimen
Specimen.definition: The kind of material that forms the specimen.
Specimen.comment: The type can change the way that a specimen is handled and drives what kind of analyses can properly be performed on the specimen. It is frequently used in diagnostic work flow decision making systems.

binding.description: The type of the specimen.

Specimen.short: Where the specimen came from. This may be from patient(s), from a location (e.g., the source of an environmental sample), or a sampling of a substance or a device
Specimen.definition: Where the specimen came from. This may be from patient(s), from a location (e.g., the source of an environmental sample), or a sampling of a substance or a device.

Specimen.short: The time when specimen was received for processing
Specimen.definition: Time when specimen was received for processing or testing.

Specimen.short: Specimen from which this specimen originated
Specimen.definition: Reference to the parent (source) specimen which is used when the specimen was either derived from or a component of another specimen.
Specimen.comment: The parent specimen could be the source from which the current specimen is derived by some processing step (e.g. an aliquot or isolate or extracted nucleic acids from clinical samples) or one of many specimens that were combined to create a pooled sample.

Specimen.definition: Details concerning a service request that required a specimen to be collected.
Specimen.comment: The request may be explicit or implied such with a ServiceRequest that requires a blood draw.

Specimen.definition: Details concerning the specimen collection.
Person who collected the specimen.
Time when specimen was collected from subject - the physiologically relevant time.

Specimen.short: How long it took to collect specimen
Specimen.definition: The span of time over which the collection of a specimen occurred.
The quantity of specimen collected; for instance the volume of a blood sample, or the physical measurement of an anatomic pathology sample.
A coded value specifying the technique that is used to perform the procedure.

binding.description: The  technique that is used to perform the procedure.

Specimen.definition: Anatomical location from which the specimen was collected (if subject is a patient). This is the target site.  This element is not used for environmental specimens.
Specimen.comment: If the use case requires  BodySite to be handled as a separate resource instead of an inline coded element (e.g. to identify and track separately)  then use the standard extension [bodySite](extension-bodysite.html).

binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

Specimen.short: Whether or how long patient abstained from food and/or drink
Specimen.definition: Abstinence or reduction from some or all food, drink, or both, for a period of time prior to sample collection.
Specimen.comment: Representing fasting status using this element is preferred to representing it with an observation using a 'pre-coordinated code'  such as  LOINC 2005-7 (Calcium [Moles/time] in 2 hour Urine --12 hours fasting), or  using  a component observation ` such as `Observation.component code`  = LOINC 49541-6 (Fasting status - Reported).

binding.description: Codes describing the fasting status of the patient.

Specimen.definition: Details concerning processing and processing steps for the specimen.
Textual description of procedure.

Specimen.short: Indicates the treatment step  applied to the specimen
Specimen.definition: A coded value specifying the procedure used to process the specimen.

binding.description: Type indicating the technique used to process the specimen.

Specimen.short: Material used in the processing step
Specimen.definition: Material used in the processing step.

Specimen.short: Date and time of specimen processing
Specimen.definition: A record of the time or period when the specimen processing occurred.  For example the time of sample fixation or the period of time the sample was in formalin.
The container holding the specimen.  The recursive nature of containers; i.e. blood in tube in tray in rack is not addressed here.
Id for container. There may be multiple; a manufacturer's bar code, lab assigned identifier, etc. The container ID may differ from the specimen id in some circumstances.
Textual description of the container.

Specimen.short: Kind of container directly associated with specimen
Specimen.definition: The type of container associated with the specimen (e.g. slide, aliquot, etc.).

binding.description: Type of specimen container.

Specimen.definition: The capacity (volume or other measure) the container may contain.
The quantity of specimen in the container; may be volume, dimensions, or other appropriate measurements, depending on the specimen type.
Introduced substance to preserve, maintain or enhance the specimen. Examples: Formalin, Citrate, EDTA.

binding.description: Substance added to specimen container.

Specimen.definition: A mode or state of being that describes the nature of the specimen.
Specimen.comment: Specimen condition is an observation made about the specimen.  It's a point-in-time assessment.  It can be used to assess its quality or appropriateness for a specific test.

binding.description: Codes describing the state of the specimen.

Specimen.definition: To communicate any details or issues about the specimen or during the specimen collection. (for example: broken vial, sent with patient, frozen).

SpecimenDefinition.short: Business identifier of a kind of specimen
SpecimenDefinition.definition: A business identifier associated with the kind of specimen.
The kind of material to be collected.

binding.description: The type of the specimen to be collected.

SpecimenDefinition.definition: Preparation of the patient for specimen collection.

binding.description: Checks on the patient prior specimen collection.

SpecimenDefinition.definition: Time aspect of specimen collection (duration or offset).
The action to be performed for collecting the specimen.

binding.description: The action to collect a type of specimen.

SpecimenDefinition.short: Specimen in container intended for testing by lab
SpecimenDefinition.definition: Specimen conditioned in a container as expected by the testing laboratory.
Primary of secondary specimen.
The kind of specimen conditioned for testing expected by lab.

binding.description: The type of specimen conditioned in a container for lab testing.

SpecimenDefinition.definition: The preference for this type of conditioned specimen.

binding.description: Degree of preference of a type of conditioned specimen.

SpecimenDefinition.definition: The specimen's container.
The type of material of the container.

binding.description: Types of material for specimen containers.

SpecimenDefinition.short: Kind of container associated with the kind of specimen
SpecimenDefinition.definition: The type of container used to contain this kind of specimen.

binding.description: Type of specimen container.

SpecimenDefinition.definition: Color of container cap.

binding.description: Color of the container cap.

SpecimenDefinition.definition: The textual description of the kind of container.
The capacity (volume or other measure) of this kind of container.
The minimum volume to be conditioned in the container.
Substance introduced in the kind of container to preserve, maintain or enhance the specimen. Examples: Formalin, Citrate, EDTA.
Substance introduced in the kind of container to preserve, maintain or enhance the specimen. Examples: Formalin, Citrate, EDTA.

binding.description: Substance added to specimen container.

SpecimenDefinition.definition: Special processing that should be applied to the container for this kind of specimen.
Requirements for delivery and special handling of this kind of conditioned specimen.
The usual time that a specimen of this kind is retained after the ordered tests are completed, for the purpose of additional testing.
Criterion for rejection of the specimen in its container by the laboratory.

binding.description: Criterion for rejection of the specimen by laboratory.

SpecimenDefinition.definition: Set of instructions for preservation/transport of the specimen at a defined temperature interval, prior the testing process.
It qualifies the interval of temperature, which characterizes an occurrence of handling. Conditions that are not related to temperature may be handled in the instruction element.

binding.description: Set of handling instructions prior testing of the specimen.

SpecimenDefinition.definition: The temperature interval for this set of handling instructions.
The maximum time interval of preservation of the specimen with these conditions.
Additional textual instructions for the preservation or transport of the specimen. For instance, 'Protect from light exposure'.

StructureDefinition.short: Canonical identifier for this structure definition, represented as a URI (globally unique)
StructureDefinition.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this structure definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this structure definition is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the structure definition is stored on different servers.
StructureDefinition.comment: Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.  The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).   In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.

StructureDefinition.short: Additional identifier for the structure definition
StructureDefinition.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this structure definition when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
StructureDefinition.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this structure definition outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.

StructureDefinition.short: Business version of the structure definition
StructureDefinition.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the structure definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the structure definition author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
StructureDefinition.comment: There may be different structure definition instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the structure definition with the format [url]|[version].

StructureDefinition.short: Name for this structure definition (computer friendly)
StructureDefinition.definition: A natural language name identifying the structure definition. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
StructureDefinition.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.Some Examples:   * O2SatObservation * PresentationReport * Immunization2 * AcmeAdmissionRecordOld.

StructureDefinition.short: Name for this structure definition (human friendly)
StructureDefinition.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the structure definition.
StructureDefinition.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.Applications don't have to use this name but can always fall back to it. The title also corresponds to the label for the root element.

StructureDefinition.short: draft | active | retired | unknown
StructureDefinition.definition: The status of this structure definition. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
StructureDefinition.comment: Allows filtering of structure definitions that are appropriate for use versus not.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

StructureDefinition.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
StructureDefinition.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this structure definition is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
StructureDefinition.comment: Allows filtering of structure definitions that are appropriate for use versus not.

StructureDefinition.short: Date last changed
StructureDefinition.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the structure definition was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the structure definition changes.
StructureDefinition.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the structure definition. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

StructureDefinition.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
StructureDefinition.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the structure definition.
StructureDefinition.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the structure definition is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the structure definition. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the structure definition. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

StructureDefinition.short: Contact details for the publisher
StructureDefinition.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
StructureDefinition.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

StructureDefinition.short: Natural language description of the structure definition
StructureDefinition.definition: A free text natural language description of the structure definition from a consumer's perspective.
StructureDefinition.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the structure definition was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the structure definition as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the structure definition is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the structure definition was created).

StructureDefinition.short: The context that the content is intended to support
StructureDefinition.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate structure definition instances.
StructureDefinition.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.

StructureDefinition.short: Intended jurisdiction for structure definition (if applicable)
StructureDefinition.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the structure definition is intended to be used.
StructureDefinition.comment: It may be possible for the structure definition to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

StructureDefinition.short: Why this structure definition is defined
StructureDefinition.definition: Explanation of why this structure definition is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
StructureDefinition.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the structure definition. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this structure definition.

StructureDefinition.short: Use and/or publishing restrictions
StructureDefinition.definition: A copyright statement relating to the structure definition and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the structure definition.

StructureDefinition.short: Assist with indexing and finding
StructureDefinition.definition: A set of key words or terms from external terminologies that may be used to assist with indexing and searching of templates nby describing the use of this structure definition, or the content it describes.

binding.description: Codes for the meaning of the defined structure (SNOMED CT and LOINC codes, as an example).

StructureDefinition.short: FHIR Version this StructureDefinition targets
StructureDefinition.definition: The version of the FHIR specification on which this StructureDefinition is based - this is the formal version of the specification, without the revision number, e.g. [publication].[major].[minor], which is 4.0.0. for this version.
StructureDefinition.comment: A StructureDefinition does not need to specify the target it applies to as StructureDefinitions will often be valid across multiple versions of FHIR. FHIR tooling can determine whether a StructureDefinition is consistent with a particular StructureDefinition if desired.

binding.description: All published FHIR Versions.

StructureDefinition.short: External specification that the content is mapped to
StructureDefinition.definition: An external specification that the content is mapped to.

StructureDefinition.short: Internal id when this mapping is used
StructureDefinition.definition: An Internal id that is used to identify this mapping set when specific mappings are made.
StructureDefinition.comment: The specification is described once, with general comments, and then specific mappings are made that reference this declaration.

StructureDefinition.short: Identifies what this mapping refers to
StructureDefinition.definition: An absolute URI that identifies the specification that this mapping is expressed to.
StructureDefinition.comment: A formal identity for the specification being mapped to helps with identifying maps consistently.

StructureDefinition.short: Names what this mapping refers to
StructureDefinition.definition: A name for the specification that is being mapped to.

StructureDefinition.short: Versions, Issues, Scope limitations etc.
StructureDefinition.definition: Comments about this mapping, including version notes, issues, scope limitations, and other important notes for usage.

StructureDefinition.short: primitive-type | complex-type | resource | logical
StructureDefinition.definition: Defines the kind of structure that this definition is describing.

binding.description: Defines the type of structure that a definition is describing.

StructureDefinition.short: Whether the structure is abstract
StructureDefinition.definition: Whether structure this definition describes is abstract or not  - that is, whether the structure is not intended to be instantiated. For Resources and Data types, abstract types will never be exchanged  between systems.
StructureDefinition.comment: Abstract Resources cannot be instantiated - a concrete sub-type must be used. Abstract datatypes and extensions cannot be used in an instance. For logical models, the exact implication of "abstract" will rest with the author, depending how the logical model is used. Flagging a constraint structure as abstract conveys design intent but makes no difference to how the structure definition is handled. Note that inline declared elements that are given the type "Element" in the StructureDefinition, but have children described, are anonymous concrete types that specialize Element.

StructureDefinition.short: If an extension, where it can be used in instances
StructureDefinition.definition: Identifies the types of resource or data type elements to which the extension can be applied.

StructureDefinition.short: fhirpath | element | extension
StructureDefinition.definition: Defines how to interpret the expression that defines what the context of the extension is.

binding.description: How an extension context is interpreted.

StructureDefinition.short: Where the extension can be used in instances
StructureDefinition.definition: An expression that defines where an extension can be used in resources.

StructureDefinition.short: FHIRPath invariants - when the extension can be used
StructureDefinition.definition: A set of rules as FHIRPath Invariants about when the extension can be used (e.g. co-occurrence variants for the extension). All the rules must be true.
StructureDefinition.comment: The rules are only evaluated when the extension is present. When evaluating the invariant, the FHIRPath focus is the element that holds the extension, and %extension refers to the extension itself.

StructureDefinition.short: Type defined or constrained by this structure
StructureDefinition.definition: The type this structure describes. If the derivation kind is 'specialization' then this is the master definition for a type, and there is always one of these (a data type, an extension, a resource, including abstract ones). Otherwise the structure definition is a constraint on the stated type (and in this case, the type cannot be an abstract type).  References are URLs that are relative to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition e.g. "string" is a reference to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/string. Absolute URLs are only allowed in logical models.
StructureDefinition.comment: Note that in the case of constraints, the type could be determined by chasing through the baseDefinition references until a concrete structure (derivation = specialization) is reached, or by looking at the path of the first element in the snapshot - if present - but providing the type directly makes for simpler tooling and indexing.   The type must match the elements defined in the differential and the snapshot. For all FHIR defined types, the path name of the element will start with the type name. For logical models, where the type is a URL, the type name SHOULD start with the tail of the type URL where required.

binding.description: Either a resource or a data type, including logical model types.

StructureDefinition.short: Definition that this type is constrained/specialized from
StructureDefinition.definition: An absolute URI that is the base structure from which this type is derived, either by specialization or constraint.
StructureDefinition.comment: If differential constraints are specified in this structure, they are applied to the base in a "differential" fashion. If there is no base, then the differential constraints cannot be provided (snapshot only). Differential structures are useful for the editing perspective, and snapshot structures are suitable for operational use. The FHIR Project provides a number of tools/services to populate snapshots from differential constraints. Logical Models have a base of "Element" or another logical model.

StructureDefinition.short: specialization | constraint - How relates to base definition
StructureDefinition.definition: How the type relates to the baseDefinition.
StructureDefinition.comment: If the definition is a specialization, then it adds new elements in the differential, and the snapshot includes the inherited elements.  If the definition is a constraint, then it cannot define new elements, it can only make new rules about existing content (see [Profiling Resources](profiling.html#resources)).

binding.description: How a type relates to its baseDefinition.

StructureDefinition.short: Snapshot view of the structure
StructureDefinition.definition: A snapshot view is expressed in a standalone form that can be used and interpreted without considering the base StructureDefinition.

StructureDefinition.short: Definition of elements in the resource (if no StructureDefinition)
StructureDefinition.definition: Captures constraints on each element within the resource.

StructureDefinition.short: Differential view of the structure
StructureDefinition.definition: A differential view is expressed relative to the base StructureDefinition - a statement of differences that it applies.

StructureDefinition.short: Definition of elements in the resource (if no StructureDefinition)
StructureDefinition.definition: Captures constraints on each element within the resource.

StructureMap.short: Canonical identifier for this structure map, represented as a URI (globally unique)
StructureMap.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this structure map when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this structure map is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the structure map is stored on different servers.
StructureMap.comment: Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.  The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).   In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.

StructureMap.short: Additional identifier for the structure map
StructureMap.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this structure map when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
StructureMap.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this structure map outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.

StructureMap.short: Business version of the structure map
StructureMap.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the structure map when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the structure map author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
StructureMap.comment: There may be different structure map instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the structure map with the format [url]|[version].

StructureMap.short: Name for this structure map (computer friendly)
StructureMap.definition: A natural language name identifying the structure map. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
StructureMap.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.

StructureMap.short: Name for this structure map (human friendly)
StructureMap.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the structure map.
StructureMap.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

StructureMap.short: draft | active | retired | unknown
StructureMap.definition: The status of this structure map. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
StructureMap.comment: Allows filtering of structure maps that are appropriate for use versus not.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

StructureMap.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
StructureMap.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this structure map is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
StructureMap.comment: Allows filtering of structure maps that are appropriate for use versus not.

StructureMap.short: Date last changed
StructureMap.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the structure map was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the structure map changes.
StructureMap.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the structure map. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

StructureMap.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
StructureMap.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the structure map.
StructureMap.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the structure map is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the structure map. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the structure map. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

StructureMap.short: Contact details for the publisher
StructureMap.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
StructureMap.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

StructureMap.short: Natural language description of the structure map
StructureMap.definition: A free text natural language description of the structure map from a consumer's perspective.
StructureMap.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the structure map was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the structure map as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the structure map is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the structure map was created).

StructureMap.short: The context that the content is intended to support
StructureMap.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate structure map instances.
StructureMap.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.

StructureMap.short: Intended jurisdiction for structure map (if applicable)
StructureMap.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the structure map is intended to be used.
StructureMap.comment: It may be possible for the structure map to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

StructureMap.short: Why this structure map is defined
StructureMap.definition: Explanation of why this structure map is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
StructureMap.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the structure map. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this structure map.

StructureMap.short: Use and/or publishing restrictions
StructureMap.definition: A copyright statement relating to the structure map and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the structure map.

StructureMap.short: Structure Definition used by this map
StructureMap.definition: A structure definition used by this map. The structure definition may describe instances that are converted, or the instances that are produced.
StructureMap.comment: It is not necessary for a structure map to identify any dependent structures, though not listing them may restrict its usefulness.

StructureMap.short: Canonical reference to structure definition
StructureMap.definition: The canonical reference to the structure.

StructureMap.short: source | queried | target | produced
StructureMap.definition: How the referenced structure is used in this mapping.

binding.description: How the referenced structure is used in this mapping.

StructureMap.short: Name for type in this map
StructureMap.definition: The name used for this type in the map.
StructureMap.comment: This is needed if both types have the same name (e.g. version conversion).

StructureMap.short: Documentation on use of structure
StructureMap.definition: Documentation that describes how the structure is used in the mapping.

StructureMap.short: Other maps used by this map (canonical URLs)
StructureMap.definition: Other maps used by this map (canonical URLs).

StructureMap.short: Named sections for reader convenience
StructureMap.definition: Organizes the mapping into manageable chunks for human review/ease of maintenance.

StructureMap.short: Human-readable label
StructureMap.definition: A unique name for the group for the convenience of human readers.

StructureMap.short: Another group that this group adds rules to
StructureMap.definition: Another group that this group adds rules to.

StructureMap.short: none | types | type-and-types
StructureMap.definition: If this is the default rule set to apply for the source type or this combination of types.
StructureMap.comment: Not applicable if the underlying model is untyped. There can only be one default mapping for any particular type combination.

binding.description: If this is the default rule set to apply for the source type, or this combination of types.

StructureMap.short: Additional description/explanation for group
StructureMap.definition: Additional supporting documentation that explains the purpose of the group and the types of mappings within it.

StructureMap.short: Named instance provided when invoking the map
StructureMap.definition: A name assigned to an instance of data. The instance must be provided when the mapping is invoked.
StructureMap.comment: If no inputs are named, then the entry mappings are type based.

StructureMap.short: Name for this instance of data
StructureMap.definition: Name for this instance of data.

StructureMap.short: Type for this instance of data
StructureMap.definition: Type for this instance of data.

StructureMap.short: source | target
StructureMap.definition: Mode for this instance of data.

binding.description: Mode for this instance of data.

StructureMap.short: Documentation for this instance of data
StructureMap.definition: Documentation for this instance of data.

StructureMap.short: Transform Rule from source to target
StructureMap.definition: Transform Rule from source to target.

StructureMap.short: Name of the rule for internal references
StructureMap.definition: Name of the rule for internal references.

StructureMap.short: Source inputs to the mapping
StructureMap.definition: Source inputs to the mapping.

StructureMap.short: Type or variable this rule applies to
StructureMap.definition: Type or variable this rule applies to.

StructureMap.short: Specified minimum cardinality
StructureMap.definition: Specified minimum cardinality for the element. This is optional; if present, it acts an implicit check on the input content.

StructureMap.short: Specified maximum cardinality (number or *)
StructureMap.definition: Specified maximum cardinality for the element - a number or a "*". This is optional; if present, it acts an implicit check on the input content (* just serves as documentation; it's the default value).

StructureMap.short: Rule only applies if source has this type
StructureMap.definition: Specified type for the element. This works as a condition on the mapping - use for polymorphic elements.

StructureMap.short: Default value if no value exists
StructureMap.definition: A value to use if there is no existing value in the source object.
StructureMap.comment: If there's a default value on an item that can repeat, it will only be used once.

StructureMap.short: Optional field for this source
StructureMap.definition: Optional field for this source.

StructureMap.short: first | not_first | last | not_last | only_one
StructureMap.definition: How to handle the list mode for this element.

binding.description: If field is a list, how to manage the source.

StructureMap.short: Named context for field, if a field is specified
StructureMap.definition: Named context for field, if a field is specified.

StructureMap.short: FHIRPath expression  - must be true or the rule does not apply
StructureMap.definition: FHIRPath expression  - must be true or the rule does not apply.

StructureMap.short: FHIRPath expression  - must be true or the mapping engine throws an error instead of completing
StructureMap.definition: FHIRPath expression  - must be true or the mapping engine throws an error instead of completing.

StructureMap.short: Message to put in log if source exists (FHIRPath)
StructureMap.definition: A FHIRPath expression which specifies a message to put in the transform log when content matching the source rule is found.
StructureMap.comment: This is typically used for recording that something Is not transformed to the target for some reason.

StructureMap.short: Content to create because of this mapping rule
StructureMap.definition: Content to create because of this mapping rule.

StructureMap.short: Type or variable this rule applies to
StructureMap.definition: Type or variable this rule applies to.

StructureMap.short: type | variable
StructureMap.definition: How to interpret the context.

binding.description: How to interpret the context.

StructureMap.short: Field to create in the context
StructureMap.definition: Field to create in the context.

StructureMap.short: Named context for field, if desired, and a field is specified
StructureMap.definition: Named context for field, if desired, and a field is specified.

StructureMap.short: first | share | last | collate
StructureMap.definition: If field is a list, how to manage the list.

binding.description: If field is a list, how to manage the production.

StructureMap.short: Internal rule reference for shared list items
StructureMap.definition: Internal rule reference for shared list items.

StructureMap.short: create | copy +
StructureMap.definition: How the data is copied / created.

binding.description: How data is copied/created.

StructureMap.short: Parameters to the transform
StructureMap.definition: Parameters to the transform.

StructureMap.short: Parameter value - variable or literal
StructureMap.definition: Parameter value - variable or literal.

StructureMap.definition: Variable to pass to the rule or group.

StructureMap.definition: Documentation for this instance of data.

Subscription.definition: The status of the subscription, which marks the server state for managing the subscription.
Subscription.comment: A client can only submit subscription resources in the requested or off state. Only the server can  move a subscription from requested to active, and then to error. Either the server or the client can turn a subscription off.  This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.description: The status of a subscription.

Subscription.definition: Contact details for a human to contact about the subscription. The primary use of this for system administrator troubleshooting.

Subscription.short: When to automatically delete the subscription
Subscription.definition: The time for the server to turn the subscription off.
Subscription.comment: The server is permitted to deviate from this time but should observe it.

Subscription.short: Description of why this subscription was created
Subscription.definition: A description of why this subscription is defined.
The rules that the server should use to determine when to generate notifications for this subscription.
Subscription.comment: The rules are search criteria (without the [base] part). Like Bundle.entry.request.url, it has no leading "/".

Subscription.definition: A record of the last error that occurred when the server processed a notification.

Subscription.short: The channel on which to report matches to the criteria
Subscription.definition: Details where to send notifications when resources are received that meet the criteria.
The type of channel to send notifications on.

binding.description: The type of method used to execute a subscription.

Subscription.definition: The url that describes the actual end-point to send messages to.
Subscription.comment: For rest-hook, and websocket, the end-point must be an http: or https: URL; for email, a mailto: url, for sms, a tel: url, and for message the endpoint can be in any form of url the server understands (usually, http: or mllp:). The URI is allowed to be relative; in which case, it is relative to the server end-point (since there may be more than one, clients should avoid using relative URIs).

Subscription.short: MIME type to send, or omit for no payload
Subscription.definition: The mime type to send the payload in - either application/fhir+xml, or application/fhir+json. If the payload is not present, then there is no payload in the notification, just a notification. The mime type "text/plain" may also be used for Email and SMS subscriptions.
Subscription.comment: Sending the payload has obvious security implications. The server is responsible for ensuring that the content is appropriately secured.

binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

Subscription.short: Usage depends on the channel type
Subscription.definition: Additional headers / information to send as part of the notification.
Subscription.comment: Exactly what these mean depend on the channel type. They can convey additional information to the recipient and/or meet security requirements; for example, support of multiple headers in the outgoing notifications for rest-hook type subscriptions.

Substance.comment: This identifier is associated with the kind of substance in contrast to the  Substance.instance.identifier which is associated with the package/container.

Substance.definition: A code to indicate if the substance is actively used.

binding.description: A code to indicate if the substance is actively used.

Substance.short: What class/type of substance this is
Substance.definition: A code that classifies the general type of substance.  This is used  for searching, sorting and display purposes.
Substance.comment: The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set.   More fine-grained filtering can be performed using the metadata and/or terminology hierarchy in Substance.code.

binding.description: Category or classification of substance.

Substance.definition: A code (or set of codes) that identify this substance.
Substance.comment: This could be a reference to an externally defined code.  It could also be a locally assigned code (e.g. a formulary),  optionally with translations to the standard drug codes.

binding.description: Substance codes.

Substance.short: Textual description of the substance, comments
Substance.definition: A description of the substance - its appearance, handling requirements, and other usage notes.

Substance.short: If this describes a specific package/container of the substance
Substance.definition: Substance may be used to describe a kind of substance, or a specific package/container of the substance: an instance.
Identifier associated with the package/container (usually a label affixed directly).

Substance.short: When no longer valid to use
Substance.definition: When the substance is no longer valid to use. For some substances, a single arbitrary date is used for expiry.

Substance.short: Amount of substance in the package

Substance.definition: A substance can be composed of other substances.
The amount of the ingredient in the substance - a concentration ratio.
Another substance that is a component of this substance.

binding.description: Substance Ingredient codes.

SupplyDelivery.definition: Identifier for the supply delivery event that is used to identify it across multiple disparate systems.
SupplyDelivery.comment: This identifier is typically assigned by the dispenser, and may be used to reference the delivery when exchanging information about it with other systems.

SupplyDelivery.definition: A plan, proposal or order that is fulfilled in whole or in part by this event.
A larger event of which this particular event is a component or step.
SupplyDelivery.comment: Not to be used to link an event to an Encounter - use Event.context for that.  [The allowed reference resources may be adjusted as appropriate for the event resource].

SupplyDelivery.definition: A code specifying the state of the dispense event.
SupplyDelivery.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.description: Status of the supply delivery.

SupplyDelivery.short: Patient for whom the item is supplied
SupplyDelivery.definition: A link to a resource representing the person whom the delivered item is for.
Indicates the type of dispensing event that is performed. Examples include: Trial Fill, Completion of Trial, Partial Fill, Emergency Fill, Samples, etc.

binding.description: The type of supply dispense.

SupplyDelivery.short: The item that is delivered or supplied
SupplyDelivery.definition: The item that is being delivered or has been supplied.
The amount of supply that has been dispensed. Includes unit of measure.
Identifies the medication, substance or device being dispensed. This is either a link to a resource representing the details of the item or a code that identifies the item from a known list.

binding.description: The item that was delivered.

SupplyDelivery.definition: The date or time(s) the activity occurred.
SupplyDelivery.comment: [The list of types may be constrained as appropriate for the type of event].

SupplyDelivery.definition: The individual responsible for dispensing the medication, supplier or device.
Identification of the facility/location where the Supply was shipped to, as part of the dispense event.
Identifies the person who picked up the Supply.

SupplyRequest.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this SupplyRequest by the author and/or other systems. These identifiers remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
SupplyRequest.comment: The identifier.type element is used to distinguish between the identifiers assigned by the requester/placer and the performer/filler.

binding.description: Status of the supply request.

SupplyRequest.short: The kind of supply (central, non-stock, etc.)
SupplyRequest.definition: Category of supply, e.g.  central, non-stock, etc. This is used to support work flows associated with the supply process.

binding.description: Category of supply request.

SupplyRequest.definition: Indicates how quickly this SupplyRequest should be addressed with respect to other requests.

binding.description: Identifies the level of importance to be assigned to actioning the request.

SupplyRequest.short: Medication, Substance, or Device requested to be supplied
SupplyRequest.definition: The item that is requested to be supplied. This is either a link to a resource representing the details of the item or a code that identifies the item from a known list.
SupplyRequest.comment: Note that there's a difference between a prescription - an instruction to take a medication, along with a (sometimes) implicit supply, and an explicit request to supply, with no explicit instructions.

binding.description: The item that was requested.

SupplyRequest.short: The requested amount of the item indicated
SupplyRequest.definition: The amount that is being ordered of the indicated item.
Specific parameters for the ordered item.  For example, the size of the indicated item.
A code or string that identifies the device detail being asserted.

binding.description: A code that identifies the device detail.

SupplyRequest.definition: The value of the device detail.
SupplyRequest.comment: Range means device should have a value that falls somewhere within the specified range.

SupplyRequest.short: When the request should be fulfilled
SupplyRequest.definition: When the request should be fulfilled.
The device, practitioner, etc. who initiated the request.

SupplyRequest.short: Who is intended to fulfill the request
SupplyRequest.definition: Who is intended to fulfill the request.

SupplyRequest.short: The reason why the supply item was requested
SupplyRequest.definition: The reason why the supply item was requested.

binding.description: The reason why the supply item was requested.

SupplyRequest.short: The reason why the supply item was requested
SupplyRequest.definition: The reason why the supply item was requested.
Where the supply is expected to come from.
Where the supply is destined to go.

Task.definition: The business identifier for this task.
The URL pointing to a *FHIR*-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this Task.
The URL pointing to an *externally* maintained  protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this Task.

BasedOn refers to a higher-level authorization that triggered the creation of the task.  It references a "request" resource such as a ServiceRequest, MedicationRequest, ServiceRequest, CarePlan, etc. which is distinct from the "request" resource the task is seeking to fulfill.  This latter resource is referenced by FocusOn.  For example, based on a ServiceRequest (= BasedOn), a task is created to fulfill a procedureRequest ( = FocusOn ) to collect a specimen from a patient.
An identifier that links together multiple tasks and other requests that were created in the same context.
Task that this particular task is part of.
The current status of the task.

binding.description: The current status of the task.

Task.definition: An explanation as to why this task is held, failed, was refused, etc.
Task.comment: This applies to the current status.  Look at the history of the task to see reasons for past statuses.

binding.description: Codes to identify the reason for current status.  These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.

Task.definition: Contains business-specific nuances of the business state.

binding.description: The domain-specific business-contextual sub-state of the task.  For example: "Blood drawn", "IV inserted", "Awaiting physician signature", etc.

Task.short: unknown | proposal | plan | order | original-order | reflex-order | filler-order | instance-order | option
Task.definition: Indicates the "level" of actionability associated with the Task, i.e. i+R[9]Cs this a proposed task, a planned task, an actionable task, etc.
Task.comment: This element is immutable.  Proposed tasks, planned tasks, etc. must be distinct instances.  In most cases, Tasks will have an intent of "order".

binding.description: Distinguishes whether the task is a proposal, plan or full order.

Task.definition: Indicates how quickly the Task should be addressed with respect to other requests.

binding.description: The task's priority.

Task.definition: A name or code (or both) briefly describing what the task involves.
Task.comment: The title (eg "My Tasks", "Outstanding Tasks for Patient X") should go into the code.

binding.description: Codes to identify what the task involves.  These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.

Task.definition: A free-text description of what is to be performed.
The request being actioned or the resource being manipulated by this task.
Task.comment: If multiple resources need to be manipulated, use sub-tasks.  (This ensures that status can be tracked independently for each referenced resource.).

Task.definition: The entity who benefits from the performance of the service specified in the task (e.g., the patient).

Task.short: Healthcare event during which this task originated
Task.definition: The healthcare event  (e.g. a patient and healthcare provider interaction) during which this task was created.

Task.short: Start and end time of execution
Task.definition: Identifies the time action was first taken against the task (start) and/or the time final action was taken against the task prior to marking it as completed (end).
The date and time this task was created.
The date and time of last modification to this task.

Task.short: Who is asking for task to be done
Task.definition: The creator of the task.
The kind of participant that should perform the task.

binding.description: The type(s) of task performers allowed.

Task.definition: Individual organization or Device currently responsible for task execution.
Task.comment: Tasks may be created with an owner not yet identified.

Task.definition: Principal physical location where the this task is performed.
A description or code indicating why this task needs to be performed.
Task.comment: This should only be included if there is no focus or if it differs from the reason indicated on the focus.

binding.description: Indicates why the task is needed.  E.g. Suspended because patient admitted to hospital.

Task.definition: A resource reference indicating why this task needs to be performed.
Task.comment: Tasks might be justified based on an Observation, a Condition, a past or planned procedure, etc.   This should only be included if there is no focus or if it differs from the reason indicated on the focus.    Use the CodeableConcept text element in `Task.reasonCode` if the data is free (uncoded) text.

Task.definition: Insurance plans, coverage extensions, pre-authorizations and/or pre-determinations that may be relevant to the Task.
Free-text information captured about the task as it progresses.

Task.short: Key events in history of the Task
Task.definition: Links to Provenance records for past versions of this Task that identify key state transitions or updates that are likely to be relevant to a user looking at the current version of the task.
Task.comment: This element does not point to the Provenance associated with the *current* version of the resource - as it would be created after this version existed.  The Provenance for the current version can be retrieved with a _revinclude.

Task.definition: If the Task.focus is a request resource and the task is seeking fulfillment (i.e. is asking for the request to be actioned), this element identifies any limitations on what parts of the referenced request should be actioned.
Indicates the number of times the requested action should occur.
Over what time-period is fulfillment sought.
Task.comment: Note that period.high is the due date representing the time by which the task should be completed.

Task.definition: For requests that are targeted to more than on potential recipient/target, for whom is fulfillment sought?
Additional information that may be needed in the execution of the task.
A code or description indicating how the input is intended to be used as part of the task execution.
Task.comment: If referencing a BPMN workflow or Protocol, the "system" is the URL for the workflow definition and the code is the "name" of the required input.

binding.description: Codes to identify types of input parameters.  These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.  E.g. "Comparison source", "Applicable consent", "Concomitent Medications", etc.

Task.short: Content to use in performing the task
Task.definition: The value of the input parameter as a basic type.

Task.short: Information produced as part of task
Task.definition: Outputs produced by the Task.
The name of the Output parameter.

binding.description: Codes to identify types of input parameters.  These will typically be specific to a particular workflow.  E.g. "Identified issues", "Preliminary results", "Filler order", "Final results", etc.

Task.definition: The value of the Output parameter as a basic type.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: Canonical identifier for this terminology capabilities, represented as a URI (globally unique)
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this terminology capabilities when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this terminology capabilities is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the terminology capabilities is stored on different servers.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.  The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).   In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: Business version of the terminology capabilities
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the terminology capabilities when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the terminology capabilities author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: There may be different terminology capabilities instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the terminology capabilities with the format [url]|[version].

TerminologyCapabilities.short: Name for this terminology capabilities (computer friendly)
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: A natural language name identifying the terminology capabilities. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: Name for this terminology capabilities (human friendly)
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the terminology capabilities.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

TerminologyCapabilities.definition: The status of this terminology capabilities. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: Allows filtering of terminology capabilitiess that are appropriate for use versus not.This is not intended for use with actual capability statements, but where capability statements are used to describe possible or desired systems.

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this terminology capabilities is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: Allows filtering of terminology capabilitiess that are appropriate for use versus not.

TerminologyCapabilities.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the terminology capabilities was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the terminology capabilities changes.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the terminology capabilities. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the terminology capabilities.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the terminology capabilities is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the terminology capabilities. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the terminology capabilities. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

TerminologyCapabilities.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: Natural language description of the terminology capabilities
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: A free text natural language description of the terminology capabilities from a consumer's perspective. Typically, this is used when the capability statement describes a desired rather than an actual solution, for example as a formal expression of requirements as part of an RFP.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the terminology capabilities was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the terminology capabilities as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the terminology capabilities is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the terminology capabilities was created).This does not need to be populated if the description is adequately implied by the software or implementation details.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: The context that the content is intended to support
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate terminology capabilities instances.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: Intended jurisdiction for terminology capabilities (if applicable)
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the terminology capabilities is intended to be used.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: It may be possible for the terminology capabilities to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: Why this terminology capabilities is defined
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: Explanation of why this terminology capabilities is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the terminology capabilities. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this terminology capabilities.

TerminologyCapabilities.definition: A copyright statement relating to the terminology capabilities and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the terminology capabilities.

The way that this statement is intended to be used, to describe an actual running instance of software, a particular product (kind, not instance of software) or a class of implementation (e.g. a desired purchase).

binding.description: How a capability statement is intended to be used.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: Software that is covered by this terminology capability statement
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: Software that is covered by this terminology capability statement.  It is used when the statement describes the capabilities of a particular software version, independent of an installation.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: A name the software is known by
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: Name the software is known by.
The version identifier for the software covered by this statement.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: If possible, a version should be specified, as statements are likely to be different for different versions of software.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: If this describes a specific instance
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: Identifies a specific implementation instance that is described by the terminology capability statement - i.e. a particular installation, rather than the capabilities of a software program.
Information about the specific installation that this terminology capability statement relates to.
An absolute base URL for the implementation.
Whether the server supports lockedDate.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: A code system supported by the server
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: Identifies a code system that is supported by the server. If there is a no code system URL, then this declares the general assumptions a client can make about support for any CodeSystem resource.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: The code system - identified by its system URL - may also be declared explicitly as a Code System Resource at /CodeSystem, but it might not be.

TerminologyCapabilities.definition: URI for the Code System.
For the code system, a list of versions that are supported by the server.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: Language translations might not be available for all codes.

TerminologyCapabilities.definition: For version-less code systems, there should be a single version with no identifier.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: If this is the default version for this code system
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: If this is the default version for this code system.
If the compositional grammar defined by the code system is supported.
Language Displays supported.
Filter Properties supported.
Code of the property supported.
Operations supported for the property.
Properties supported for $lookup.
True if subsumption is supported for this version of the code system.
Information about the [ValueSet/$expand](valueset-operation-expand.html) operation.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: Whether the server can return nested value sets
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: Whether the server can return nested value sets.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: Whether the server supports paging on expansion
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: Whether the server supports paging on expansion.
Allow request for incomplete expansions?
Supported expansion parameter.
Expansion Parameter name.
Description of support for parameter.
Documentation about text searching works.
TerminologyCapabilities.comment: This documentation should cover things like case sensitivity,  use of punctuation if not ignored, what wild cards are supported (if any), whether text is starts with or contains, and whether word order matters.

TerminologyCapabilities.definition: The degree to which the server supports the code search parameter on ValueSet, if it is supported.

binding.description: The degree to which the server supports the code search parameter on ValueSet, if it is supported.

TerminologyCapabilities.definition: Information about the [ValueSet/$validate-code](valueset-operation-validate-code.html) operation.
Whether translations are validated.
Information about the [ConceptMap/$translate](conceptmap-operation-translate.html) operation.

TerminologyCapabilities.short: Whether the client must identify the map
TerminologyCapabilities.definition: Whether the client must identify the map.
Whether the $closure operation is supported.
If cross-system closure is supported.

TestReport.short: External identifier
TestReport.definition: Identifier for the TestScript assigned for external purposes outside the context of FHIR.

TestReport.short: Informal name of the executed TestScript
TestReport.definition: A free text natural language name identifying the executed TestScript.
TestReport.comment: Not expected to be globally unique.

TestReport.short: completed | in-progress | waiting | stopped | entered-in-error
TestReport.definition: The current state of this test report.
TestReport.comment: The status represents where the execution is currently within the test script execution life cycle.  This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.description: The current status of the test report.

TestReport.short: Reference to the  version-specific TestScript that was executed to produce this TestReport
TestReport.definition: Ideally this is an absolute URL that is used to identify the version-specific TestScript that was executed, matching the `TestScript.url`.

TestReport.short: pass | fail | pending
TestReport.definition: The overall result from the execution of the TestScript.
TestReport.comment: The pass and fail result represents a completed test script execution. The pending result represents a test script execution that has not yet started or is currently in progress.

binding.description: The reported execution result.

TestReport.short: The final score (percentage of tests passed) resulting from the execution of the TestScript
TestReport.definition: The final score (percentage of tests passed) resulting from the execution of the TestScript.

TestReport.short: Name of the tester producing this report (Organization or individual)
TestReport.definition: Name of the tester producing this report (Organization or individual).
TestReport.comment: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

TestReport.short: When the TestScript was executed and this TestReport was generated
TestReport.definition: When the TestScript was executed and this TestReport was generated.
TestReport.comment: Additional specific dates may be added as extensions.

TestReport.short: A participant in the test execution, either the execution engine, a client, or a server
TestReport.definition: A participant in the test execution, either the execution engine, a client, or a server.

TestReport.short: test-engine | client | server
TestReport.definition: The type of participant.

binding.description: The type of participant.

TestReport.short: The uri of the participant. An absolute URL is preferred
TestReport.definition: The uri of the participant. An absolute URL is preferred.

TestReport.short: The display name of the participant
TestReport.definition: The display name of the participant.

TestReport.short: The results of the series of required setup operations before the tests were executed
TestReport.definition: The results of the series of required setup operations before the tests were executed.

TestReport.short: A setup operation or assert that was executed
TestReport.definition: Action would contain either an operation or an assertion.
TestReport.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both.  It can contain any number of variables.

TestReport.short: The operation to perform
TestReport.definition: The operation performed.

TestReport.short: pass | skip | fail | warning | error
TestReport.definition: The result of this operation.

binding.description: The results of executing an action.

TestReport.short: A message associated with the result
TestReport.definition: An explanatory message associated with the result.

TestReport.short: A link to further details on the result
TestReport.definition: A link to further details on the result.

TestReport.short: The assertion to perform
TestReport.definition: The results of the assertion performed on the previous operations.

TestReport.short: pass | skip | fail | warning | error
TestReport.definition: The result of this assertion.

binding.description: The results of executing an action.

TestReport.short: A message associated with the result
TestReport.definition: An explanatory message associated with the result.

TestReport.short: A link to further details on the result
TestReport.definition: A link to further details on the result.

TestReport.short: A test executed from the test script
TestReport.definition: A test executed from the test script.

TestReport.short: Tracking/logging name of this test
TestReport.definition: The name of this test used for tracking/logging purposes by test engines.

TestReport.short: Tracking/reporting short description of the test
TestReport.definition: A short description of the test used by test engines for tracking and reporting purposes.

TestReport.short: A test operation or assert that was performed
TestReport.definition: Action would contain either an operation or an assertion.
TestReport.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both.  It can contain any number of variables.

TestReport.short: The results of running the series of required clean up steps
TestReport.definition: The results of the series of operations required to clean up after all the tests were executed (successfully or otherwise).

TestReport.short: One or more teardown operations performed
TestReport.definition: The teardown action will only contain an operation.
TestReport.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both.  It can contain any number of variables.

TestScript.short: Canonical identifier for this test script, represented as a URI (globally unique)
TestScript.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this test script when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this test script is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the test script is stored on different servers.
TestScript.comment: Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.  The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).   In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.

TestScript.short: Additional identifier for the test script
TestScript.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this test script when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
TestScript.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this test script outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.

TestScript.short: Business version of the test script
TestScript.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the test script when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the test script author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
TestScript.comment: There may be different test script instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the test script with the format [url]|[version].

TestScript.short: Name for this test script (computer friendly)
